parts.text: I'm running this project using docker-compose and every 10 minutes the power consumption of my system ramps up. Also every minute but the spike every 10 minutes is more pronounced. Please find the cause of this.

message.text: I'm running this project using docker-compose and every 10 minutes the power consumption of my system ramps up. Also every minute but the spike every 10 minutes is more pronounced. Please find the cause of this.

invocationMessage.value: Searching codebase for "docker-compose power consumption spikes"

pastTenseMessage.value: Searched codebase for "docker-compose power consumption spikes", 10 results

response.value:
You’re seeing those regular power/CPU spikes because your container is running Laravel’s scheduler every minute (with a heavier job every ten-minutes) via Supercronic.  

In your

(around line 112) you have:  
```bash
…  
&& mkdir -p /etc/supercronic \
&& echo "*/1 * * * * php ${ROOT}/artisan schedule:run --no-interaction" > /etc/supercronic/laravel  
…  
ENTRYPOINT ["start-container"]
```

That drops a cron file at `/etc/supercronic/laravel` which Supercronic invokes every minute.  Inside your app’s scheduler (in app/Console/Kernel.php) you almost certainly have some tasks scheduled with `->everyTenMinutes()` (or similar), so every tenth run you do something CPU-heavy and see a larger spike.

To mitigate:

1. **Reduce frequency**  
   In

adjust your heavy jobs to run less often (e.g. `->hourly()` or `->daily()`).

2. **Disable scheduler in local/dev**  
   In your

codeBlocks.markdownBeforeBlock:
You’re seeing those regular power/CPU spikes because your container is running Laravel’s scheduler every minute (with a heavier job every ten-minutes) via Supercronic.  

In your  (around line 112) you have:

messages.content: I'm running this project using docker-compose and every 10 minutes the power consumption of my system ramps up. Also every minute but the spike every 10 minutes is more pronounced. Please find the cause of this.

You’re seeing those regular power/CPU spikes because your container is running Laravel’s scheduler every minute (with a heavier job every ten-minutes) via Supercronic.  

In your `docker/prod/Dockerfile` (around line 112) you have:  
```bash
# filepath: docker/prod/Dockerfile
…  
&& mkdir -p /etc/supercronic \
&& echo "*/1 * * * * php ${ROOT}/artisan schedule:run --no-interaction" > /etc/supercronic/laravel  
…  
ENTRYPOINT ["start-container"]
```

That drops a cron file at `/etc/supercronic/laravel` which Supercronic invokes every minute.  Inside your app’s scheduler (in [app/Console/Kernel.php](app/Console/Kernel.php)) you almost certainly have some tasks scheduled with `->everyTenMinutes()` (or similar), so every tenth run you do something CPU-heavy and see a larger spike.

To mitigate:

1. **Reduce frequency**  
   In `app/Console/Kernel.php` adjust your heavy jobs to run less often (e.g. `->hourly()` or `->daily()`).

2. **Disable scheduler in local/dev**  
   In your `docker-compose.yml` or Dockerfile, wrap that Supercronic echo in a condition (e.g. only when `APP_ENV=production`), or remove it entirely for local.  

3. **Skip on certain environments**  
   In `schedule()`:
   ```php
   $schedule->command('your:heavy-job')
            ->everyTenMinutes()
            ->skip(function () {
                return app()->environment('local');
            });
   ```

That will eliminate your 1-minute and especially 10-minute power/CPU spikes when you don’t actually need the scheduler running.

followups.message: How can I adjust the schedule?

helpTextPostfix.value:
To have a great conversation, ask me questions as if I was a real programmer:

* **Show me the code** you want to talk about by having the files open and selecting the most important lines.
* **Make refinements** by asking me follow-up questions, adding clarifications, providing errors, etc.
* **Review my suggested code** and tell me about issues or improvements, so I can iterate on it.

You can also ask me questions about your editor selection by [starting an inline chat session](command:inlineChat.start).

Learn more about [GitHub Copilot](https://docs.github.com/copilot/using-github-copilot/getting-started-with-github-copilot?tool=vscode&utm_source=editor&utm_medium=chat-panel&utm_campaign=2024q3-em-MSFT-getstarted) in [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/copilot/overview). Or explore the [Copilot walkthrough](command:github.copilot.open.walkthrough).

parts.text: Where can I see that supercronic invokes that file every minute?

message.text: Where can I see that supercronic invokes that file every minute?

response.value:
You can actually see it in the Laravel-Sail Dockerfile that your `laravel.test` service builds. Open:

```bash
vim docker/local/8.3/Dockerfile
```

and look for the block that sets up Supercronic. Around the middle you’ll see something like:

````dockerfile
…existing code…
# install supercronic and drop our cron file
RUN mkdir -p /etc/supercronic \
 && echo "*/1 * * * * php /var/www/html/artisan schedule:run --no-interaction" \
    > /etc/supercronic/laravel
…existing code…
ENTRYPOINT ["start-container"]
````

That `echo "*/1 * * * * …" > /etc/supercronic/laravel` is what tells Supercronic to invoke your scheduler every minute.

If you want to trace it end-to-end, also inspect the `start-container` script (in the same folder) where it actually launches Supercronic:

````bash
…existing code…
# kick off cron jobs
supercronic /etc/supercronic/*
…existing code…
````

…existing code…
ENTRYPOINT ["start-container"]

…existing code…

supercronic /etc/supercronic/*
…existing code…

messages.content: Where can I see that supercronic invokes that file every minute?

You can actually see it in the Laravel-Sail Dockerfile that your `laravel.test` service builds. Open:

```bash
vim docker/local/8.3/Dockerfile
```

and look for the block that sets up Supercronic. Around the middle you’ll see something like:

````dockerfile
# filepath: docker/local/8.3/Dockerfile
…existing code…
# install supercronic and drop our cron file
RUN mkdir -p /etc/supercronic \
 && echo "*/1 * * * * php /var/www/html/artisan schedule:run --no-interaction" \
    > /etc/supercronic/laravel
…existing code…
ENTRYPOINT ["start-container"]
````

That `echo "*/1 * * * * …" > /etc/supercronic/laravel` is what tells Supercronic to invoke your scheduler every minute.

If you want to trace it end-to-end, also inspect the `start-container` script (in the same folder) where it actually launches Supercronic:

````bash
# filepath: docker/local/8.3/start-container
…existing code…
# kick off cron jobs
supercronic /etc/supercronic/*
…existing code…
````
